file.content:
--- theme: ../ ---
Let's Connect
X (Twitter)
My Website
LinkedIn
Questions? Want to discuss your AI engineering challenges?

└── 10-conclusion/
    ├── Let's Connect - QR codes (X, LinkedIn, Website)
    └── Questions?
```

## Diagrams

*Mermaid or ASCII diagrams as understanding develops*

## Notes

*Working notes, ideas, considerations*

- The "Occam's Razor" framing is powerful - overcomplicated AI setups are the enemy
- The loop pattern (iterate until it works, then step out) feels like a key insight
- "Separate Concerns" could be a structural principle for the skills section
- The agent-session skill in this very repo could be a meta-example

---
*Spec finalized on 2025-01-07. Ready for `/plan` phase.*

lines:
-
Questions? Want to discuss your AI engineering challenges?

+
Questions? Let's talk about building skills for your team.

-Thank you for joining me today. I hope this gave you a practical understanding of Claude Code and how it can enhance your engineering workflow without compromising your craft. Let's continue the conversation - reach out with your questions, challenges, or success stories.
+- Remember: Skills = encoding your engineering knowledge for compound gains over time
+- Start small - work IN the loop first, then systematize what works
+- The math is a no-brainer: $10K → $40K value (4x ROI)
+- What processes does your team repeat that could become skills?
+- What's blocking you from getting more value from AI coding tools?
+- Want help setting up skills for your specific workflow?
+- X/Twitter for daily AI engineering insights
+- Website for consulting and deeper engagements
+Thank them for their time and attention!

file.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # Example: My Skills Setup
This is how I work - not comprehensive, but practical.
.claude/
settings.json
skills/
agent-session/
commit/
pr-review/
prime/
...
I have a lot of skills/commands built out - each one codifies a workflow I do repeatedly.

What's in a Skill?

SKILL.md
Entry point - describes what the skill does and when to use it
Workflows
Step-by-step processes the agent follows
References
Examples, templates, domain knowledge
This standardizes a process you + agent can leverage

--- theme: ../ layout: center ---
[Bell Curve Meme Placeholder]
Image: skill-issue.jpg to be added
Left Side
"Let AI Write the Code"
Middle (crying)
"AI Cannot Match My Skills"
Right Side
"Let AI Write the Code"
But don't let bad examples blind you to the opportunity

file.content:
--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # The Problem
90% AI adoption, zero standardization
+20%
PRs per author
+23.5%
Incidents per PR
+30%
Change failure rate
"AI amplifies whatever you have"
I've seen this firsthand:
Recent client project - UI engineer using Cursor without understanding
5000+ line files, hardcoded strings, 20 components per file
Not his fault - he didn't know what he was doing

--- theme: ../ layout: center --- # The Question
Now that we've defined the problem...
What are we doing in 2026 to fix this?
What should you allocate your time and resources to?
How do you build TRUST into your AI system?

--- theme: ../ layout: center --- # The Proof
+114,427
lines of code added
~$864
spent on Claude Code
$23,480
income (December)
"95% of the code was written by AI"

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # This Isn't New

Working with a Junior Engineer

1. You determine what the task should be
2. You hand it off
3. You review the PR
? HOW it gets done? You don't control that

But There's Standardization

- Commit rules
- Tests must pass
- GitHub Actions
- Company protocols
- Documentation
The same docs you'd give a new junior = what you give the LLM

--- theme: ../ layout: speaker --- # About Me
Applied AI Engineer & Consultant
### Background - 3 years Full-time in Gen AI - ~2 years building agentic systems - Built **30+ Gen AI Projects** ::speaker-name:: Ford Lascari ::image::

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # How Skills Work

The Flow

1.
Model sees: "I have these skills available"
2.
Model thinks: "I need to acquire this skill"
3. Model reads the skill files
4. Knowledge is now IN the context

File Structure

.claude/skills/
my-skill/
SKILL.md
references/
workflow.md
examples.md
Progressive Disclosure
Only load context when needed - keeps the context window lean

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # Key Takeaways

The Message

Don't let bad examples blind you
This technology is coming - learn to use it well
For skilled engineers, AI is a HUGE force multiplier
The people who know what good looks like win
Skills = compound gains over time
Encoding your knowledge into reusable processes

The Math

Token spend per engineer: ~$1,000/mo
10 engineers token spend: $10,000/mo
Average engineer cost: ~$10,000/mo
40% more effective = $40,000 value
Spend $10K → Get $40K value 4x ROI
The Mentality Shift
"What can we systematize into skills?" → Transfer best practices to the whole team

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # The Vision

Encoding Your Knowledge

→
First: Agent does flows you already do efficiently
→
Then: Trust builds → queue as background task → just review
→
Goal: Step farther and farther out of the loop

Reality Check: The "10x" Myth

10x output is NOT instant transformation
Reality: 10% faster here, 5% faster there
These compound over MONTHS
No magic pill - AI does NOT replace knowledge
You're building TOWARDS that future, not there yet
Don't "just let AI handle it" - but build toward it.

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # What is a Skill?
📄
Opinionated Markdown Files
A structured way to format documentation that agents can understand
🔍
Self-Discovery
Agent can discover and acquire processes within the skill on-demand
🏛️
Becoming Standard
Anthropic recently released this structure - it's becoming the standard
✅
Not Complicated
You already have the knowledge - skills just encode it properly

--- theme: ../ layout: default --- # Building Skills: Occam's Razor

The Common Mistake

Give everything to the agent right away
"Here's my whole workflow, figure it out"
Result: Bad skills. The flow isn't tested. It's not based on YOUR actual process.

The Right Approach

1.
Work IN the loop first
Do the work alongside the agent manually
2.
Iterate until you're happy
Refine the process through real use
3.
THEN step out
"How can I take myself out of it?"
Keep it as simple as possible.
Don't add complexity until you actually need it.

tool_input.old_string:
<!--
This is the vision we're working toward. With skills, you're encoding your engineering knowledge so the agent can do the flows you already do efficiently. As trust builds, you start queuing tasks as background work and just review the output. The goal is stepping farther and farther out of the loop.

But let me be real - this isn't instant 10x transformation. That's a myth. The reality is 10% faster here, 5% faster there, and these compound over MONTHS. There's no magic pill. AI does NOT replace the knowledge you need to have. You're building toward that future, not arriving at it overnight.

Don't just hand everything off and expect miracles - but DO build systematically toward more autonomy over time.
-->

lines: This is the vision we're working toward. With skills, you're encoding your engineering knowledge so the agent can do the flows you already do efficiently. As trust builds, you start queuing tasks as background work and just review the output. The goal is stepping farther and farther out of the loop.

But let me be real - this isn't instant 10x transformation. That's a myth. The reality is 10% faster here, 5% faster there, and these compound over MONTHS. There's no magic pill. AI does NOT replace the knowledge you need to have. You're building toward that future, not arriving at it overnight.

+TIMING: Approaching final 3 minutes of content before Q&A.

    - text: The Skill Issue a.k.a. "The Bell Curve Meme" Left Side "Let AI Write the Code" Middle (crying) "AI Cannot Match My Skills" Right Side "Let AI Write the Code" But don't let bad examples blind you to the opportunity 1 0 1
    - slider [ref=s2e197]: "1"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e199]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e203]: "Everyone has seen this meme. The key insight is the REFRAME: both ends of the bell curve let AI write code, but for VERY different reasons. On the left, it's ignorance. On the right, it's mastery - knowing HOW to guide the AI effectively. The middle is stuck in fear. For skilled engineers, AI is a HUGE force multiplier."
    - text: 59 words 4
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e208]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e211]
    - heading "About Me" [level=1] [ref=s2e222]
    - text: Applied AI Engineer & Consultant
    - heading "Background" [level=3] [ref=s2e224]
    - list [ref=s2e225]:
      - listitem [ref=s2e226]: 3 years Full-time in Gen AI
      - listitem [ref=s2e227]: ~2 years building agentic systems
      - listitem [ref=s2e228]:
        - text: Built
        - strong [ref=s2e229]: 30+ Gen AI Projects
    - heading "Ford Lascari" [level=2] [ref=s2e231]:
      - paragraph [ref=s2e232]: Ford Lascari
    - img "Ford Lascari" [ref=s2e235]
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e237]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e241]: Quick intro - I've been doing this full-time for three years, two of those specifically building agentic systems. 30+ projects across different industries. But credentials don't prove value - the next slide does.
    - text: 33 words 5
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e246]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e249]
    - heading "The Proof" [level=1] [ref=s2e259]
    - text: +114,427 lines of code added ~$864 spent on Claude Code $23,480 income (December) "95% of the code was written by AI" 4 0 1 2 3 4
    - slider [ref=s2e291]: "4"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e293]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e297]: This isn't a flex - it's proof that real value IS possible. These aren't demo numbers, these are production systems making real money.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e298]: "The key insight: I'm not special. I just figured out how to encode my engineering knowledge so the AI can use it effectively. That's what skills are about - and that's what we're going to cover."
    - text: 59 words 6
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e303]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e306]
    - heading "The Question" [level=1] [ref=s2e316]
    - text: Now that we've defined the problem... What are we doing in 2026 to fix this? What should you allocate your time and resources to? How do you build TRUST into your AI system? 4 0 1 2 3 4
    - slider [ref=s2e343]: "4"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e345]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e349]: "SPEAKER NOTES (Pivot Point - ~3 min mark):"
    - paragraph [ref=s2e350]: "This is the pivot point. We've established the problem - 90% adoption, quality tanking, AI amplifying whatever you already have. Now the question becomes: what do we actually DO about it? How do you move from \"AI writes bad code\" to \"AI writes code I can trust\"? The answer isn't more compute or fancier models - it's about encoding YOUR knowledge. Let's talk about the mental model first."
    - paragraph [ref=s2e351]: "TRANSITION: From problem to solution section."
    - text: 82 words 7
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e356]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e359]
    - heading "This Isn’t New" [level=1] [ref=s2e368]
    - heading "Working with a Junior Engineer" [level=3] [ref=s2e371]
    - text: 1. You determine what the task should be 2. You hand it off 3. You review the PR ? HOW it gets done? You don't control that
    - heading "But There's Standardization" [level=3] [ref=s2e386]
    - text: "- Commit rules - Tests must pass - GitHub Actions - Company protocols - Documentation The same docs you'd give a new junior = what you give the LLM 6 0 1 2 3 4 5 6"
    - slider [ref=s2e432]: "6"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e434]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e438]: This isn't a new concept - every engineering team already does this. When you onboard a junior engineer, you don't control HOW they write code line by line. You give them the task, the context, the standards, and you review the output. The key is implicit and explicit standardization - commit rules, tests, CI/CD, documentation. The goal with skills is to transition that standardization into something the LLM can act upon. The same docs you'd hand a new hire? That's what you encode for the AI.
    - text: 87 words 8
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e443]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e446]
    - heading "What is a Skill?" [level=1] [ref=s2e455]
    - text: 📄 Opinionated Markdown Files A structured way to format documentation that agents can understand 🔍 Self-Discovery Agent can discover and acquire processes within the skill on-demand 🏛️ Becoming Standard Anthropic recently released this structure - it's becoming the standard ✅ Not Complicated You already have the knowledge - skills just encode it properly 4 0 1 2 3 4
    - slider [ref=s2e497]: "4"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e499]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e503]: "SPEAKER NOTES (Skills Section Start - ~5 min mark, 5-7 min for this section):"
    - paragraph [ref=s2e504]: So what IS a skill? It's an opinionated way of formatting Markdown files that allows AI agents to self-discover processes. Think of it like documentation that the AI can actually use. Anthropic recently released this as a standard structure in Claude Code, and it's becoming the de facto way to encode engineering knowledge for AI. The good news? It's not complicated to set up - if you've ever written documentation for a new hire, you've already done 80% of the work.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e505]: "NOTE: Keep skills section light touch - 5-7 minutes total for slides 07-10."
    - text: 108 words 9
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e510]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e513]
    - heading "How Skills Work" [level=1] [ref=s2e522]
    - heading "The Flow" [level=3] [ref=s2e525]
    - text: 1. Model sees:"I have these skills available" 2. Model thinks:"I need to acquire this skill" 3. Model reads the skill files 4. Knowledge is now IN the context
    - heading "File Structure" [level=3] [ref=s2e544]
    - text: .claude/skills/ my-skill/ SKILL.md references/ workflow.md examples.md Progressive Disclosure Only load context when needed - keeps the context window lean 6 0 1 2 3 4 5 6
    - slider [ref=s2e581]: "6"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e583]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e587]: Here's the magic of how skills work. The model sees a list of available skills in the system prompt. When it needs to do something, it thinks "I should acquire this skill" and reads the skill files. Now that knowledge is IN the context window - the agent has your engineering knowledge on demand.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e588]: "The file structure is simple: SKILL.md is the main entry point, and references/ contains linked documentation for different workflows. This enables progressive disclosure - the agent only loads what it needs, when it needs it."
    - text: 90 words 10
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e593]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e596]
    - 'heading "Example: My Skills Setup" [level=1] [ref=s2e605]'
    - text: This is how I work - not comprehensive, but practical. .claude/ settings.json skills/ agent-session/ commit/ pr-review/ prime/ ... I have a lot of skills/commands built out - each one codifies a workflow I do repeatedly.
    - heading "What's in a Skill?" [level=3] [ref=s2e622]
    - text: SKILL.md Entry point - describes what the skill does and when to use it Workflows Step-by-step processes the agent follows References Examples, templates, domain knowledge This standardizes a process you + agent can leverage 4 0 1 2 3 4
    - slider [ref=s2e656]: "4"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e658]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e662]: Here's what my actual Claude Code config looks like. I have skills for different workflows - agent sessions for planning, commit for standardized commits, PR review, priming context, and more. Each skill encodes a workflow I do repeatedly.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e663]: "A skill typically has a SKILL.md as the entry point, workflow definitions that the agent follows step-by-step, and references for examples and domain knowledge. The key insight: this standardizes a process that BOTH you and the agent can use. You know exactly what the agent will do because you defined it."
    - paragraph [ref=s2e664]: Light touch here - we're spending 5-7 minutes total on the skills section. The goal is understanding, not comprehensive coverage.
    - text: 110 words 11
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e669]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e672]
    - 'heading "Building Skills: Occam’s Razor" [level=1] [ref=s2e681]'
    - heading "The Common Mistake" [level=3] [ref=s2e684]
    - text: "Give everything to the agent right away \"Here's my whole workflow, figure it out\" Result: Bad skills. The flow isn't tested. It's not based on YOUR actual process."
    - heading "The Right Approach" [level=3] [ref=s2e692]
    - text: 1. Work IN the loop first Do the work alongside the agent manually 2. Iterate until you're happy Refine the process through real use 3. THEN step out "How can I take myself out of it?" Keep it as simple as possible. Don't add complexity until you actually need it. 3 0 1 2 3
    - slider [ref=s2e729]: "3"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e731]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e735]: The biggest mistake people make with skills is trying to hand everything to the agent right out of the gate. They dump a whole workflow and expect magic. The result? Bad skills. The flow isn't tested, and it's not based on YOUR actual working process.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e736]: "The right approach is Occam's Razor style. First, work IN the loop - do the work alongside the agent manually. Iterate until you're happy with how it flows. THEN ask yourself: \"How can I take myself out of this?\" That's when you codify it into a skill."
    - paragraph [ref=s2e737]: Keep it as simple as possible. Don't add complexity until you need it. Start small, validate it works, then expand.
    - text: 112 words 12
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e742]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e745]
    - heading "The Vision" [level=1] [ref=s2e754]
    - heading "Encoding Your Knowledge" [level=3] [ref=s2e757]
    - text: → First:Agent does flows you already do efficiently → Then:Trust builds → queue as background task → just review → Goal:Step farther and farther out of the loop
    - 'heading "Reality Check: The \"10x\" Myth" [level=3] [ref=s2e775]'
    - text: "10x output is NOT instant transformation Reality: 10% faster here, 5% faster there These compound over MONTHS No magic pill - AI does NOT replace knowledge You're building TOWARDS that future, not there yet Don't \"just let AI handle it\" - but build toward it. 5 0 1 2 3 4 5"
    - slider [ref=s2e812]: "5"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e814]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e818]: "SPEAKER NOTES (Closing Section - ~12 min mark):"
    - paragraph [ref=s2e819]: This is the vision we're working toward. With skills, you're encoding your engineering knowledge so the agent can do the flows you already do efficiently. As trust builds, you start queuing tasks as background work and just review the output. The goal is stepping farther and farther out of the loop.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e820]: But let me be real - this isn't instant 10x transformation. That's a myth. The reality is 10% faster here, 5% faster there, and these compound over MONTHS. There's no magic pill. AI does NOT replace the knowledge you need to have. You're building toward that future, not arriving at it overnight.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e821]: Don't just hand everything off and expect miracles - but DO build systematically toward more autonomy over time.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e822]: "TIMING: Approaching final 3 minutes of content before Q&A."
    - text: 139 words 13
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e827]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e830]
    - heading "Key Takeaways" [level=1] [ref=s2e839]
    - heading "The Message" [level=3] [ref=s2e842]
    - text: Don't let bad examples blind you This technology is coming - learn to use it well For skilled engineers, AI is a HUGE force multiplier The people who know what good looks like win Skills = compound gains over time Encoding your knowledge into reusable processes
    - heading "The Math" [level=3] [ref=s2e854]
    - text: "Token spend per engineer: ~$1,000/mo 10 engineers token spend: $10,000/mo Average engineer cost: ~$10,000/mo 40% more effective = $40,000 value Spend $10K → Get $40K value 4x ROI The Mentality Shift \"What can we systematize into skills?\" → Transfer best practices to the whole team 5 0 1 2 3 4 5"
    - slider [ref=s2e899]: "5"
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e901]
    - paragraph [ref=s2e905]: Here are the key takeaways. First, don't let bad examples blind you. Yes, there are people making a mess with AI coding tools - but this technology is coming whether you like it or not. Learn to use it well.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e906]: For skilled engineers - people who know what good code looks like - AI is a HUGE force multiplier. You're the ones who benefit most because you can steer it effectively.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e907]: Let's do the math. Each engineer using about $1,000/month in tokens. 10 engineers = $10K spend. An average engineer costs about $10K/month. If your team is 40% more effective, that's $40K in value. You're spending $10K to get $40K. That's 4x ROI. This is a no-brainer investment.
    - paragraph [ref=s2e908]: "The mentality shift is asking: \"What can we systematize into skills?\" Take the best practices from your top performers and transfer them to the whole team through skills. That's how you scale quality."
    - text: 153 words 14
    - button "Play in new tab" [ref=s2e913]
    - button "Open in editor" [ref=s2e916]
    - text: Let's Connect
    - img "X QR Code" [ref=s2e930]
    - link "X (Twitter)" [ref=s2e932]:
      - /url: https://x.com/intent/follow?screen_name=FJ000RD
    - img "Website QR Code" [ref=s2e936]
    - link "My Website" [ref=s2e938]:
      - /url: https://lascari.ai/consulting/
    - img "LinkedIn QR Code" [ref=s2e942]
    - link "LinkedIn" [ref=s2e944]:
      - /url: https://www.linkedin.com/in/ford-lascari/
    - text: Questions? Let's talk about building skills for your team.
    - button "Edit Note" [ref=s2e947]
